definitions.definition: to use pictures, photographs, diagrams, etc. in a book, etc.

examples.text: His lecture was illustrated with photos taken during the expedition.
The new edition is heavily illustrated with photographs of aircraft.
Quentin Blake was tasked with illustrating the novels of Evelyn Waugh.
The volume is lavishly illustrated with drawings and photographs.

definitions.definition: to make the meaning of something clearer by using examples, pictures, etc.
definitions.sensetop: illustrate somethingillustrate something with somethingillustrate how, what, etc…

examples.text: **To illustrate my point**, let me tell you a little story.
Last year's sales figures are illustrated in Figure 2.
He is showing these silent films to help illustrate his story of survival.
Each topic is illustrated with concrete examples of economic practice.
Here's an example to illustrate what I mean.

definitions.definition: to show that something is true or that a situation exists
definitions.sensetop: illustrate somethingillustrate how, what, etc…illustrate that…

examples.text: The incident illustrates the need for better security measures.
This story illustrates how little has changed.
These data illustrate that many parents are not aware of the risks.
His question merely illustrates his ignorance of the subject.
The case tragically illustrates the dangers of fireworks.
The dire consequences of chronic underfunding are nowhere better illustrated than in the nation's schools.

wordOrigin: early 16th cent. (in the sense ‘illuminate, shed light on’): from Latin illustrat- ‘lit up’, from the verb illustrare, from in- ‘upon’ + lustrare ‘illuminate’.
